description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/lPlJZ6DyApX

This is my version of a penny catapult for use in the game SEEJ.  It has a ratchet to allow for easy tightening of the rubber band.  I have included an STL file that shows how to assemble the catapult.  The assembly file contains ASSY in the name.  The files are publicly available on tinkerCAD.com.

Step 1: Print all the parts
  • I print with 1 skin and 10% fill. I do not recommend printing this with acceleration turned on if you are using a Replicator.
  • If you are going to print all the parts at once I recommend using a raft.
  • You have some choices to make here. I have included a file that has all the parts. If you are good at printing large files then you can turn this on to print at night and wake up to all your parts in the morning. Otherwise, you can print the parts you want in groups by selecting the individual files.
  • Decide if you want to use a 1 penny or 3 penny arm. When I play SEEJ my kids and I like to play with the following rule. At the start of each round you count how many flags you have. You get one shot for each flag you have standing. You can decide if you want to load more than one penny at a time or if you want to shoot 3 at a time (a 3 penny shot costs 3 flags). Both arms allow the user to shoot the penny in two orientations â€“ flat or on edge.
    • Step 2: Assemble the Catapult
  • Using the ASSY file as a guide, assemble the catapult. I use a little supper-glue to hold the supports in place on the frames.
    • Step 3: Rubber Bands
  • Using an elastic band of some sort, create a loop between the left and right frames. Do this by pulling the elastic through the hole in the center of the ratchet/frame assembly, loop it around one of the two shortest supports from the â€œsupportsâ€ file, back through the hole and do the same thing on the other side.
  • When choosing a rubber band I have had better luck using rubber bands that are wide and that are already fairly tight before you turn the ratchets. If you use a rubber band that is too narrow you will have a hard time getting enough power out of your catapult. If you use a rubber band that is too long you will have a hard time keeping your arm straight.
    • Step 4: Power Up
  • Turn the ratchet so that the rubber band twists. Be sure to tighten both sides equally.
  • As you twist the ratchet it is a good idea to twist one side one full turn (360Â°) and then twist the other side one full turn (360Â°). This will help keep the catapult arm straight.
  • Be sure to check the arm to make sure it is not twisting.
    • Step 5: Play
  • The catapult is easy to use but there is one feature that might not be obvious. If you printed the â€œstopsâ€ they can be used to choose the angle at which your catapult shoots. Slide both of the stops out of the way to get a low straight shot. Slide the biggest stop to the center for a high shot. Slide the medium stop to the middle for a medium level shot.
    • Step 6: Enjoy!

description.text:
I changed up the design of the foregrip, so that it is held in by 2 bolts instead of just 1. I honestly didn't think that 1 bolt would be that strong, and the recoil would probably cause it to crack. With it clamped down in 2 places, the stress is more evenly distributed. Also I hollowed out the middle part a bit to save plastic. I'd recommend printing this with PETG, ABS, Polycarbonate, or Nylon-X (my personal favorite).

Obviously when slicing, rotate the foregrip 90 degrees so the flat side is on the build plate... And preferably print with a brim and an enclosure (depending on the filament type) to prevent warping.

Hardware needed:
(2) M3x30mm screws
(2) M3 nuts

description.text:
(Updated, see below)

An adapter for tool-free installation and removal of pistol grip panels. Press the detent to quickly swap between pistol grips and rifle buttstock and back again. Requires the installation of the Crosman Backpacker buttstock detent and spring near the rear screw of the pistol grip frame.

Create a horizontal flip image for the left side half. Using adhesive, join the halves together at the raised lip along the backstrap and underneath the grip adapter. Attach the Crosman grip panels to the sides of the adapter. The holes are sized so that you can apply pressure while driving the screws to form threads.

Fits Crosman and Benjamin pistols that share a common grip frame design such as the 13xx, 22xx, 1720T, Silhouette, and Marauder.

Updates:
2/1/2018 - Published
2/5/2018 - Improved fit on grip frame. Removed single-unit model (too difficult to print).
2/16/2018 - Improved fit for older grip panels and grip frames

author: rcoolen

description.text: replacement sim holder bracket lid

This is my fidget box. I know I'm a little late to the game with fidget toys, but I did this for fun and self-education mostly. It's my first upload to Thingiverse, and by far the most complicated model I've created.

This box contains 7 fidgets:

  1. Bouncy cap
  2. Magnetic push/pull
  3. Clicky button
  4. Velcro toy
  5. Magnetic spinner
  6. Fidget spinner
  7. Box spinner
    ...and a multitude of magnets for extended fun.

All the parts are easily printable with very few overhangs.

As side from the printed parts, you'll also need:

  • 24 - 6mm X 3mm disc magnets - https://tinyurl.com/ydxj8s9a
  • 2 - Fidget spinner bearings - https://goo.gl/2SfHQs
  • 1 - or 2 - 5.5 x 38mm compression spring(s) - https://goo.gl/WRg48M
  • 110 mm of - 20mm wide Velcro strip
  • 6 - 3/8-inch ball bearings - https://goo.gl/g2u8St
  • 1 - Tactile Push Button 12x12x7.3mm - https://tinyurl.com/y8rg3fwz
  • Super glue
  • Quick clamps – They work great for pressing the magnets and bearings into the holes. -
    You may also need something to hold the parts together while the super glue cures.
  • Maybe some sandpaper

Putting it together

The fidget spinner, lid, mag spinner and bouncy cap are all printed in two parts to avoid overhangs. I usually print the two lid halves in a single color. But I like printing one half of the other parts (fidget spinner, mag spinner and bouncy cap) in one color and the other half in a second color. I suggest using a little sand paper before gluing the halves together.

Push Pull – Put a magnet in each of the holes on the push/pull bar. Then put a magnet in each of the holes on the inside of the box. Make sure they line up to attract the magnets in the push/pull.

Clicky Button – You’ll have to cut the leads off of the button to make it fit in the hole correctly. You’ll also have to cut the rim off of the button, so it fits into the square hole. Just put a drop of glue one each side of the button housing and slide it into the box. Make sure you don’t push it to far it or it won’t work.

Bouncy Cap – Put a magnet in the provided 3mm hole in the outside half. Use it to lineup the two halves when you glue them together. Put one of the springs in the center of the spindle, then slide it into the box. Glue the retainer to the end of the spindle. Once it’s in place you should be able to turn the cap and the retainer should slip in to the provided groove. If you want a little more bounce, use two springs coiled together.

Mag Spinner – As with the bouncy cap, use a magnet in the center of the mag spinner to line up the two halves for gluing. Put magnets in the provided holes on the end of the box. There are four holes on the spinner. I like to put magnets in two of the holes with the poles lined up to be attracted to the magnets you just put in the box. You can also put one or two additional magnets in the spinner. Align them to be attracted to the magnets in the box or flip them to be repelled. It’s up to you, experiment. Press one of the bearings into the hole on the end of the box. Then slide the mag spinner spindle into the bearing. Use one of the two spinner cap tops to secure it.

Fidget Spinner – Press one of the bearings in to half of the fidget spinner. Use it to line up the second half for gluing. Press a ball bearing into each of the six holes. Glue a magnet to the ball in the top center of each end. On the bottom of the box put a magnet in each to the two holes near the center of the box. These will line up with the magnets on the fidget spinner and hold it in place.

Bottom – There are holes on the bottom of the box and the bottom cover for magnets. You can use them if you wish, but I prefer to just glue the bottom on.

Velcro Toy – Stick a piece of Velcro hooks on the box in the provided groove. Then cover the toy with the loops.

remixed_from.author: luc_e
remixed_from.title: Raspberry Pi 7 Inch Touchscreen display case

description.text:
More pictures posted. The lid is very basic at the moment and will be revised to better fit around the pi ethernet and USB ports. I also uploaded the snap-fit bases I made for the pi and relay. Not sure if anyone will care but it can be tough to cut out parts from a complete .STL so I left these here.

WARNING if you can't SAFELY wire the relay in to this enclosure, don't. 120v AC is deadly and not at all the same as playing with an Arduino MCU or LEDs and a 9v battery. You can die. If you do that then you won't be converting oxygen to carbon-dioxide and the trees will suffer. WHY DO YOU HATE THE TREES!!!!

I'd appreciate it if anyone has ideas for mounting this case. I had considered mounting underneath my Prusa i3MK2 by bridging the threaded rods. This way it is out of the way.

This is a remix(ish) of luc_e's Raspberry Pi 7 Inch Touchscreen display case. I sliced and diced it to make it bigger and I also added a snap-fit base for the Pi and the relay I'm using. I'll include the base for the Pi and the relay separately but the main case has everything already built in to the model. I'll make a case lid soon.

Someone will no doubt realize that I didn't make room for the SD card access. I didn't do that due to the fact that I don't plan on performing SD-card maintenance. On the rare occasion I do, I'll remove the pi. If anyone wants I could be convinced to add an opening and a tool to insert/remove the card.

I'd appreciate any comments.

title: Simple Clamp Tool for Tolerance Test

description.text:
I printed this tolerance test below using a monoprice select mini and got 0.15mm to work with a huge effort, but it would bother me for weeks that I could not get the 0.1mm to move even with all the special hammers and stuff, so I got to thinking of building a special tool to make it easy to push out the moving part and wondered if 0.1mm can pass.

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2375342

The first one I built broke - so I made it better. It seems it works much better now.

If you have no problem with precarious objects sticking well, don't use any rafts or brims. But if you want to be safe a brim can be used and easily removed .

Of course its a small clamp that can have other uses. If you figured out other uses for it, leave me a note.

Btw, I printed mine at 90% infill. No support, no raft.

Support

The support should come out fairly easily with needle nose pliers.

Hand measured the broken part and put it up in CAD. Then mirrored the part to get the other side.
. .
. .

This is an experimental idea where by putting the magnets within the effector rather than the arms. The idea of magnetic delta arms is quite attractive. Excuse the pun. Rather than placing the magnets on the end of each arm, I could imagine cylindrical magnets could be placed within the ends of the effector (also shared between adjacent nubs!). This could effectively reduce the number of magnets used for the effector by a factor of 2.

comments.text: I don't think this arrangement will provide enough magnetic attraction to hold the balls in place. While trying to set up my magnetic diagonal rods I tried some 0.3mm Teflon (PTFE) shims between the magnets and the balls to reduce friction. This small gap was enough to reduce the magnet strength so that the attraction was unreliable for holding the rods in place. In the end I abandoned the Teflon shim idea and swapped the ball/magnet configuration around. The balls are on the effector plate and the magnets are on the diagonal rods. Luckily I already had another 3D printer to make my parts, so could produce parts to experiment. Finally and because I wanted to be sure the magnets and balls don't part company in mid-print I also added some low strength elastic tensioners to hold the assemblies together end-ways on.

title: Nerf Rival Apollo Bolt Charging Adapter

description.text:
Have you purchased an Apollo and, once the giddiness of first love has passed, been left unsatisfied with the awkwardness of the charging hook? Do you gaze with envy at the charging bolt of Nerf's Helios on Target.com and wish you have gotten that one instead, but now it's too late, because you can't afford to spend another $30 on what is basically a reskinned version of the Apollo?

Say no more! SlightlyOddGuy Industries brings you the SlightlyOdd Bolt-Charging Adapter, compatible with Nerf's Apollo blaster. Gone is the necessity of putting your hand into your weapon's sightline. We put all the action out to the side in style--where it should be! Installed properly, the SlightlyOdd Bolt-Charging Adapter is the strongest, most stable, jiggle-free assembly on your Apollo blaster.

Enjoyed this design? Nay, this work of art? Check out our other Nerf-compatible items and attachments!

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

Okey Doke, listen up.

  1. Do yourself a favor and print this out of ABS.

  2. In general, a fill density of 30% will do fine for this. However, the charging bolt itself should be >/= 50%. For extra strength, paint the octagonal section of the charging bolt with acetone to seal up any areas and seams your printer didn't adhere well.

  3. Clamp the baseplates together when you glue them. They tend to want to spring outwards, which is no good. No good at all.

  4. This part requires drilling. Make sure that you pull Nerf's charging hook up through the adapter as much as you can. This will make sure that when you drill through the hook using the two smaller holes as guides, there will be as little slack as possible. Use a 1/8" drill bit.

  5. That's all the tricky parts. Glue everything else together.

  6. That gear-looking thing is non-critical. It just looks fancy. It also spins, so maybe it is critical after all!

  7. After you're all done assembling this, it should be friggin' solid. If it's not, you did something wrong.

Let me know if there are any problems with anything and I'll see what I can do!

title: Magnetic Slip Clutch for movie reels (6mm D-shaft to 8mm square shaft)

description.text:
This is a magnetic slip clutch for mounting a 16mm film reel to a motor. The input side accepts a 6mm D-profile shaft and the output side features an 8mm square shaft for mounting the reel.

In addition to the printed parts, you'll need

1 x washer (I measured around USS 1/4" dimensions, but you can use a drill to remove the inner bump and place an SAE 1/4" instead)

3 x Neodymium Ring Magnets (Magnet Source brand, sold at home depot, 9.53 mm OD and 1.53 mm thick)

1 x 1/4"-20 x 2" set screw

Also a tap and tap wrench for 1/4"-20 threads will be handy, and your choice of adhesive. I used a hot glue gun but super glue would probably be easier.

Sand the faces of the square shaft against a flat sanding surface to ensure a smooth but snug fit into your film reel. It helps to have an empty film reel handy for reference.

Tap the hole opposite the D-shaft on the driver piece for a 1/4"-20 thread until you feel resistance, at which point you've hopefully hit the D-profile section. Thread the 2" set screw into the driver piece.

Add the washer to the driver side in the washer-shaped indentation. Depending on your printer tolerances you might be able to press-fit it in, or just glue it.

Glue the three magnets (poles facing the same way) into the three circular indentations on the "magside" piece.

Make sure everything fits together and no glue is protruding from the indentations containing glued metal parts, as these will introduce unwanted extra friction.

At this point everything should fit together easily.

author: fantasticMan23

description.text: This part helps to hold the wire into a Rev module in FTC robotics. It takes some of the strain off of the wire, and keeps the wire from falling out.
customized with 3D Slash!

Dispenses a coin with each pull of the lever. Now you can live out your fantasies of being a train conductor or 50s diner waitress. More usefully, leave one in your car to make correct change at drive throughs.  
Some caps will probably be necessary, and the shoddy base could be improved. The whole thing is rather beefy as well, but I didn't want anything breaking. The dimensions could probably be reduced.

Print one base, one holder and pusher for each coin, and four cranks. The cranks should be printed with the flat side of the curved arm down. Supports will be necessary for the holders and base. The pushers fit into the trays behind their corresponding holder. They should slide very easily (there are one layer thick rails for low friction at the sides of the holder). Any rough sliding is most likely caused by unevenness at the bottom curve of the coin tower. Some judicious smoothing with a file should fix that. The straight end of the crank fits into the top of the box on the slider, and pivots on the ball hinges. Inserting them onto their hinges can be a bit tricky. Easiest is to slide the straight arm into the space between the tower and the hinge and into the slot in the box, then push it gently forward onto the balls while separating the pivot arms with your fingers. Forward tension needs to be applied on the lower arm of the crank. The original coin changers used a spring, but I found rubber bands work and are easier to come by. Some sort of printed tensioner might work. Each holder attaches to the correct slot on the base through the mating grooves. There is some built-in clearance, but because I drew them with an overhang, there is likely to be some sloppiness and some filing and muscle may be required to get them in. I have provided the CAD file, which is a DesignSpark Mechanical file. DSM is a free version of SpaceClaim, and I hope more Thingiverse users start making use of it. It is very powerful, easy to use, and reminiscent of Sketchup except you end up with manifold models instead of a mess. Watch this video to see the quarter dispenser in action. Here is the 1915 patent which this is (loosely) based on.

The cost of Philadelphia Eagles' paraphernalia is on the rise as they are on their way to the Superbowl! Print your own rather than buying on Amazon for 300% the normal price!

I printed these on 5 different printers with 0.4, 0.5 or 0.6 mm nozzles. They are all very easy parts to print. I'd recommend 0.15 mm layer heights for the spacer and football beads, and the clasps. The rest can be whatever layer height as the side walls on all the parts are vertical. A higher infill is going to give the beads more weight to droop down on the neck better. If you want a shorter necklace, 60% infill may be better, where a longer necklace may look better with 25% infill lighter beads.

My boys used regular string from the craft store (or "Embroidery Floss"). Like this:
https://www.amazon.com/Premium-Rainbow-Color-Embroidery-Floss/dp/B016HUI756/
We used a paperclip to feed the string through the beads, as the Eagles and football beads are long compared to normal beads.

EaglesClasp.stl is thinner and easier for kids to use. EaglesClasp2.stl is more robust, but it will be more difficult (esp. for kids) to clasp/unclasp. If the necklace is big enough to take off over your head, then I'd use v2.

The Letter beads come in two flavors. Version 2 has the string hole higher up on the bead so it "hangs" more. Version 1 is closer to the center for a different look, but this can cause the beads to flip around more easily.

The Eagles bead is a remix of:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1778737
The others were drawn by me in TinkerCAD or OnShape.

Go Eagles!

description.text:
I've got it printing but it's not done yet! The electronics are all still bolted to the original bottom board, and I'm working on a new enclosure for that.

PRINTED PARTS:

  • stop-holder.stl X1
  • y-axle.stl X4
  • y-bracket.stl X2
  • y-bracket.stl (MIRRORED on Y-axis!!) X2
  • y-motor-mount.stl X1
  • y-stop-mount.stl X1
  • z-motor-mount.stl X1
  • z-rail.stl X4
  • z-stop-clip v1.stl X1

EXTRUSIONS:

  • 4 x 2020 Aluminium Extrusion - Natural Anodized 440mm
  • 4 x 2020 Aluminium Extrusion - Natural Anodized 303mm
  • 4 x 2020 Aluminium Extrusion - Natural Anodized 350mm

ADDITIONAL HARDWARE:

  • 28 x Cast - 90 Degree Corner Bracket
  • 56 x Button Head Screws M5 (Length: 8mm)
  • 28 x Button Head Screws M5 (Length: 10mm)
  • 4 x 1/4"-20 x 1/2" set screws

PLEXIGLASS SIDES (Haven't actually mounted or even received it yet but here's what I ordered):

  • 2 x 12.5"x13"x1/8" clear acrylic sheet
  • 2 x 12.5"x18"x1/8 clear acrylic sheet

AND FINALLY:

  • 1 x FlashForge Creator (Wood frame edition)

My Flashforge Creator fell to the floor and broke last month. I bought a Hypercube Frame kit to replace the broken wooden frame. Then I realized it needed to be wider so I ordered four 440mm pieces from 80-20 inc. Then I discovered the drop-in nuts I had weren't compatible with 80-20 extrusions, so I bought some of their slide-in nuts which was frustrating because I'd already built the box and mounted some parts.

Anyway, I measured the living daylights out of what remained of the original wood frame with my trusty calipers, then proceeded to design and print parts that hold up the hardware and make up the difference in frame dimensions. The X gantry from the Creator was intact, so I simply mounted the Y rails. Then the Y drive axles. Then the Y motor. Then the limit switch. Rinse and repeat for the Z axis and we have a printer again.

This is a concept for a Longboard Motor Mount currently being developed for caliber 44 trucks and 50mm outrunner motor. The current plan is to use either HTD 240-5M-15 or HTD 245-5m-15 belts. The printable files will be upload mid to late February. Adaptations for 63mm motors and 12mm wide belts will also be available (Dual Drive). Current design is using 100% ABS for the motor mount which in previous tests was able to take force of the motor but whether the plastic can take the heat of the motor without warping remains to be seen.

UPDATES
1- After doing some research I came to the conclusion that the popular ESK8 motors like the ones from Maytech and APS are extremely expensive, that is why I will be using the Racestar 5045. This motor comes with a per-solder MT30 connector and support for 12S setups, they also sell a 5GT motor pulley with 15T for $3 USD. The total cost for a dual drive system will be around $100 USD which in my opinion is a great deal. The total wattage of the system will be 2200 Watts (3HP) which is comparable to something like a boosted board dual plus.

Racestar 5045 - https://www.aliexpress.com/item/High-Quality-Racerstar-5045-BRH5045-200KV-6-12S-Brushless-Motor-Electric-Motor-RC-Motor-For-Balancing/32811066037.html?spm=a2g0s.13010208.99999999.270.NNhRQv

title: Another ball bearing - some assembly required

description.text:
Plenty of other good ball bearing designs to choose from, but they looked fun to make so I gave it a quick go. It works pretty well with my settings as-is, but you may need to adjust the balls 1-2% to make it work smoothly for you.

Print the half balls (-12x) and use pliers to press fit the pin (-6x) between them for the best outcome, but printing the full balls (-6x) still works fine. They're 3/8" so using steel balls works the best.

The OD of the bearing is 1.500", the ID is .375".

To assemble put 5 balls into the OD track, put the ID in the middle of everything at a slight angle sticking outward and then forcefully push the final ball in to place. It's tight enough to be annoying to assemble, but it also keeps everything from needing support and flying everywhere once you let go. To keep the balls evenly spaced install the ring on both sides.

print_settings.Notes:: Rotating boards were printed standing up. Main reason was cosmetic. Bed adhesion is important here! Decent brim is highly recommended.

description.text:
My family has always been big on cribbage. Since deceased relative made similar cribbage boards. Upon pegging 30 points, players turn/rotate the board to continue, but now in the opposite direction. Small triangles remind players what direction they're traveling.

I wanted a crib board that would carry a deck of cards. Too simple of a drawer would slide/fall out entirely. I used a rail system that would both guide the drawer into the cribbage board and lock it in place. Inserting the drawer and it will 'drop' below the rails. Any deck of cards work as a sort of locking mechanism as it prevents the drawer from being lifted back up to the rails.

Slider and drawer required some sanding. Both are snug/friction fit. I'll upload a version that utilizes magnets instead when I get the free time to make/test.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

20

Notes:

I found a zig-zag support works well. Both in support and ease of removal. (10% support was enough for me)

Depending on bed size, model may need to be rotated to fit.

Rotating boards were printed standing up. Main reason was cosmetic. Bed adhesion is important here! Decent brim is highly recommended.

As mentioned above, some sanding was needed for a snug fit.

When glueing/assembly of the bars, boards, and knobs make sure there is a little bit of play. This will allow the board to lift/rotate. It should also be noted there are a left and a right pegging board. To make sure they are orientated correctly, place both boards next to each other. When pegging/rotating, pegs should move AWAY from the neighboring board (i.e. to the outside. Left board rotates counter-clockwise and right clockwise).

There are right and left game boards. (mirrors of each other).

comments.text: i love the idea but it would be cool if you could figure out how to make it even smaller to give it even more benefits to to traditional wooden crib boards.

This is a micro quadcopter frame I designed for FPV. It is 115mm diagonal and is made for 8.5mm brushed motors. Use tape and/or rubberbands to hold your FC and other items. This is a pretty generic frame and is made for 65mm props. The front motors have enough gap to allow for a standard camera+transmitter module with mushroom antenna.

I am using an 800mAh 25c battery w/ 5-10 minute flight time. It is a bit on the overweight side at 74g w/ battery. Max thrust should be around 100-115g I believe according to a youtube prop test. I would recommend 400-600mAh batteries.

remixed_from.title: Galaxy S7 Edge drop-in car dock (rev 2.0)

title: Honda CRV car dock cradle clip for Pixel2

description.text:
This dock is two parts:

1) A smartphone dock which is similar to a previous design, but completely redesigned using parametric modeling (stopped using sketchup). Generic phone docks you can buy on amazon use fussy springs or magnets that aren't secure. You also end up fussing with cables, or using wireless charging which not all phones have, is slow, heats your phone up a lot, and doesn't work for android auto. This is a one handed, drop it in and its connected over USB with no effort.

This smartphone dock is designed to support a google pixel 2 with a thin case on it, its 76.8mm wide, and 11.8mm deep. These dimensions are very easy to adjust in my model, so if you have a different phone, measure it and contact me and I will make new model.

The USB connector is a cheap Aukey USB-C connector, which is designed to fit perfectly, you can buy a variety pack here: https://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B01C2OAFRE/. Again, the dimensions are parameterized so If you have a different USB connector you want to use, measure it and contact me and I will make a model for you.

2) Accessory clip that custom fits into the dash of a 2017/2018 Honda CRV using tension/friction alone. There are no adhesives that leave residue, no suction cups that fail, no questionable vent clips. It doesn't require disassembling the dash, it is secure and it is easy to remove. It has a slot mechanism so you can fit different size cradles for different phones or whatever you want there. Its designed to have the phone sit to the top left of the infotainment center, it doesn't block anything and is prime unused real estate. Even though this car has android auto, I prefer to have the full version of Waze up and running while driving.

youtube video description: https://youtu.be/MFpxCm-9PE8

Both the clip and the phone were printed using ABS with 30% infill, no supports are needed.

title: Basic Collar
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is iteration two and three of my design and this is by far the comfiest. The first design was two separate pieces in PLA with locks on both sides. This proved to be very uncomfortable and would sometimes become back heavy resulting in a choking feeling. Wrapping the PLA in soft material was also of little help.

I realized that a one piece design would be the strongest and least likely to fracture under stress (resulting in sharp edges) so I removed the second lock and printed this in 95A TPU. This makes it wonderfully flexible (it will flex almost flat) and is much more comfortable around the neck, even without a cloth cover.

I used 4 shell layers top and bottom, and 3 for the sides.  Probably overkill, but they work really well. print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

description.text:
A simple 3/8" drive design that is very low height for the base to allow even deep sockets to fit in a shallow drawer. While you could redesign this to allow multiple sections to clip together, I just printed out these and applied gaffers/riggers tape on the bottom to connect them. This has worked very well and it's hard to spot there is a seam when they are in a tool box. Printed in different colors, red for SAE and blue for Metric. Standard PLA, nothing special here. Have not had any breakage issues and they just work.

Each rail can hold 9 socket pegs. If you tape two or more end to end, you can add one more at the joint between the two rails.

I'm working on an insert that will have 1/4" drive pegs but still use the same base rail to be compatible. Same for 1/2" drive.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2 layer height

Infill:

30-50%

Notes:

Sized to the max size for a Wahao i3 or Monoprice Maker Select V2. Infill needs to be fairly stout as sockets will take a toll on the pegs if you're rough with them. I used 4 shell layers top and bottom, and 3 for the sides. Probably overkill, but they work really well. Support only needed for the overhang of the rails and is very easy to remove leaving a very clean print.
Recommend once the supports are pulled free that you run each printed insert through a rail multiple times to clean up any cruft. They will break in fairly quickly and be smooth in short time.
Tinkercad was used for a simple cross section. Measured various sockets and extensions to determine the size of the pegs to be undersized for easy insertion of sockets to the pegs.

title: Dual Switching Extruder Servo rotating no ooze

description.text:
This is still a work in progress.
Edit Feb 4-2018: Added a new Parts cooling Fan for the left side for better clearance.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JipLZppDMAk

First off, a big thanks from Galaxyman7 and his support on this project.
BACKGROUND:
This project is a remix from:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2187379
I wanted to modify this to servo drive instead of mechanical drive.
I wanted to keep this partially universal to keep the number of printed parts down so I used this modular x-carriage which was a remix of one of the most popular but with BLTouch mounts. Other brackets can be found by following the links within this one as well.
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2007048
This project still takes a lot of patience to get setup correctly. Servo angles are a bit finicky to adjust and the shields have to be perfectly aligned to stop the flow of filament and not snag on the parts you are printing.
PARTS:
2 E3D V6 hotends
1 MG90D Servo (an SG90 may work but I wanted stronger)
2 608 Bearings
2 5015 Fans
2 6x3 magnets
2 3x1.5 magnets
3 3x25mm socket bolts
6 3x8mm socket bolts
4 3x10mm socket bolts
8 3mm nuts
3 4x12mm socket bolts to hold bracket to Carriage
3 4mm nuts for above
1 Metal to cut shields from, I used a duct pipe
1 4’ ziptie to secure the hotend wires and the cooling fan into the fan shroud.
Optional
3 Cotton insulators for hotends and Kapton tape to prevent Thermal Runaway.

SWITCHING:
There are 2 ways you can control the servo to switch. You can either write script in the slicer or modify the firmware to control switching. I personally modified the firmware which allows me to use any slicer without writing a script for each.
FIRMWARE:
In Marlin you will want to activate SWITCHING_NOZZLE in Configuration.h.
// A dual-nozzle that uses a servomotor to raise/lower one of the nozzles

define SWITCHING_NOZZLE

if ENABLED(SWITCHING_NOZZLE)

define SWITCHING_NOZZLE_SERVO_NR 1 // This is your Servo Number, Match to your configuration

define SWITCHING_NOZZLE_SERVO_ANGLES { 123, 58 } //Angles for E0, E1 Set these to your Calibration

//#define HOTEND_OFFSET_Z { 0.0, 0.0 } // I haven’t used these but could be an option to correct for height misalignment.

endif

Confirm you have the number of servo’s defined and wait times associated for them.
/**

  • Number of servos
  • For some servo-related options NUM_SERVOS will be set automatically.
  • Set this manually if there are extra servos needing manual control.
  • Leave undefined or set to 0 to entirely disable the servo subsystem.
    */

    define NUM_SERVOS 2 // Servo index starts with 0 for M280 command

// Delay (in milliseconds) before the next move will start, to give the servo time to reach its target angle.
// 300ms is a good value but you can try less delay.
// If the servo can't reach the requested position, increase it.

define SERVO_DELAY { 375,375 } //Modified

Once this is uploaded, anytime in the g-code T0 or T1 activates it will switch that servo.

SLICER:

The G-code (Marlin) for moving a Servo is:
M280 P(0 or 1) S(ANGLE) ; There are no brackets used when you type that in ex: M280 P1 S90

So in the Tool Change script in your slicer you would enter the following:

{IF NEWTOOL=0}M280 P1 S100 ;Where 1 = your servo number and 100 will be your servo angle for E0
{IF NEWTOOL=1}M280 P1 S34;Where 1 = your servo number and 34 will be your servo angle for E1

You could get fancy here and add codes to cool the inactive nozzle and heat the active nozzle back up. I so far found I did not need to do this but there may be situations such as using PVA where you would want to remove the heat from the nozzle.

CONSTRUCTION:

I printed all parts with PETG which is strong, flexible and able to withstand the temps at the hotends. For most parts I used 5 perimeters for additional strength and 60% infill.
I printed both the hotend holders vertical so the bearing dowel was upright to ensure the most accurate fit through the bearing. This takes a fair amount of support which can be minimized using Simplify3D multi process, use 10 support up to about 48mm then increase to 35%.
The Carriage should be printed upside down but will need support for above the bearing where the rotating hotend slides into and rotates around.

  • Press the bearings into the carriage.
  • Assemble the rotating hotend front and back with the hotends inside. These can be removed later but the 3x25 bolts need to be completely removed for the hotends to slide in or out.
  • Mount the 3x1.5 magnets into the hotend front cover. Make sure that the polarity is the same direction for both of them.
  • Then mount the 6x3 magnets into the carriage. Ensure you have the polarity the correct way so they snap together with the hotend Front cap in both directions. I was able to use large plyers to snug fit the magnets in without glue. DO NOT USE HEAT OR THEY WILL LOSE THEIR MAGNITISM AT 80C.
  • You will want to insert the rotating hotend into the carriage while it is free and not mounted to the modular x-carriage. This gives it the needed flexibility to open wide enough to slide it into the bearings. It should snap into the bearings tightly.
  • Before you connect your Servo for the first time, you will want to centre it at 90 and make sure you have 66 degrees of movement on it. You can do this with the following command:
  • M280 P1 S90 (if you are using Servo0 then this will be P0). From there you will want to slowly move the servo forward and back until it connects. If the servo is told to move too far it will lock and not move back to the previous location and you will have to remove the servo from the bracket to relieve the pressure in it. Once you determine the locations of the servo for E0 and E1 record them (in either your slicer or the firmware).
  • Attach the rotating hotend onto the modular x-carriage.
  • Lower the nozzles to the bed (glass). Using your slicer to control the printer activate E1 and adjust the height of it so it matches the height of E0.
  • Attach the hotend cooling fan shroud with the 5015 fan.
  • Secure the hotend wires to the back of the fan shroud through the fan hole.
  • Mount the nozzle shields. You will want them bent at 20 degrees to the bed so the nozzle is completely flush against the shield when parked. I would suggest to bend the tip of the shield up like a ski in case it hits a blob in the future so it does not bend backwards. Ensure the shield is completely above the bed and the active nozzle. This whole process can take some time to get everything set just right.
  • Mount the parts cooling fan.
    You will want to print a dual extruder calibration test. The following works out great to measure your offsets in both the X and Y axis. Expect your Y to be in around the 1mm range as due to extrusion errors the rotating head may not be perfectly aligned.
    https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:533814

BOARD CONNECTIONS:

I am running a MKS Base V1.5.
I have my BLTouch on PINS 11 for Servo0. I used PINS 12 for Servo1 that operates the servo to switch the Hotend.
My firmware was setup to use PINS 12 for the PSU Shutoff, If you are using that you can redefine any of the X,Y, or Z + endstops as a servo for the hotend.
In your firmware this should be in PINS.h or PINS_Ramps.h or similar.

title: Creality CR-10 Top Mount Spool Holder V2 - Easy Swap

description.text:
I created the V1 Top Mount Spool Holder for the Creality CR-10 earlier, in the link below.
The downside is the tedious process of removing support materials from the Cone Lock and also when changing filament spool will require me to turn/rotate the lock many rounds.
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2607281

Improvement

  1. Now comes the V2, which can be lock/unlock with just a 35mm screw as lock pin! CONVENIENCE!
  2. this has variable holes location so you can make minor adjustment that allow your spool to rotate smoothly
  3. Being top mount saves space! by raising your printed and have the control box beneath it
    https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2607316

Instruction
User A
If you are printing my spool holder for the first time, print everything in the file.
And screws required as below,
2x M4 short spare screw that came with printer
2x M4 spare stopper that came with printer (or purchase here https://go.edwardrc.com/2DS7EZZ)
2x M4 25cm(thread length) screw
2x M4 nut or lock nut
1x M3 35mm socket head cap screw

Assemble "Cylinder Spool Holder V2" to the "Spool Holder Bracket" with M4 25cm screw and a. M4 lock nut.
b. Slot the M3 35mm screw into the Pin Head. Superglue if it's loose
c. Remove the 2 screws near extruder(carefully of the lock washer underneath!), put on the "Filament Feeder V3" and put back the screw, could be tricky to line up.
require bed leveling calibration after this
d. now mount your "Spool Holder Bracket" onto the top rail of your printer with 2x M4 short screw and stopper that came as spare with your printer
e. load your filament spool, adjust & lock the cone to your desire position with the various hole position

User B
If you printed my V1 before, just print everything except the "Bracket", then swap them

Where to get Creality CR-10
https://www.banggood.com/DIY-Creality-CR-10-3D-Printer-300300400mm-Printing-Size-1_75mm-0_4mm-Nozzle-p-1085645.html?p=DG23031123036201501P

Printer:

Creality CR-10

Resolution:

0.3 will do

Infill:

would recomment 50% for strength

description.text:
3 axis stage used for Bath interferometer. Hardware uses .25 in Stainless Steel or drill rod for rails. K&S 9/32 inch thin wall .014 inch brass tube. 8x32 threaded rod. 6 x32 screws and 8x32 hex nuts and lock nuts.

Originally made in PLA on a Rostock Max V2 3D printer.
Parts were all printed rotated 90 deg from the .stl file shown. That is they are are flat on the build plate with the large flat side on it.

First try to make the XSlider new part. It has openings for both the .25 and 9/32 parts. If those fit then you are good to go. The .25 should be a tight fit. The 9/32 should clip into the part.and should not move too easily but can be moved with a little force.

Feb23 updated ytable.stl file for a tighter connection.

Hardware Needed.

Hardware needed:
8 8-32 hex nuts
3 8-32 lock nuts
2 one foot 8-32 threaded rods.
2 .25 inch x 1 foot stainless steel rods
2 9/32 inch OD .014 wall thickness x 1 foot brass tubing

Two of the threaded rods need to be cut to 5" and 5.5". The other length is shown in the annotated picture.

Assemblying the X stage slide

The original y control had more backlash than I liked. It was still usable but I tried a different approach with version 2. Two parts were modified. The x slider and the y table. You will find these with the version 2 appended to them. There is also a new Fusion360 model that includes these parts.

Y table version 2 with threaded control now vertical to help eliminate backlash. Also requires a new x slider to be printed.

title: filament spool axle with spring-loaded clips

description.text:
This spool axle takes 52mm diameter spools and uses two standard 608ZZ ball bearings. Feel free to use those higher-friction cheap ones, they are actually better suited because they'll act as a gentle brake. It comes with spring- (or rubber band) -loaded movable clips to secure the filament spool against sideways slippage.

One clip per tube should suffice, but two or three offer some redundancy.

To attach the clips, use a small rubber band through the clip's hole and over one spoke on the other end of the tube, then press in the bearings to prevent the bands from slipping off.

To insert/remove a filament spool: pull out the clips until they can be swiveled by 90 degrees so they both fit through the spool's inner hole.

description.text:
C5W Bulb Holder (Position Lights)

This model was made with TinkerCAD, to replace the original bulb holders of a Land Rover Serie 1 (1952) that had completely rusted and was no longer stable.

Can be adapted for any headlight that is at least 42mm in diameter.

The bulb is held by pressure / tension of the support (no possible movement, perfect fit). It will be necessary to add 2 contactor males of 0,8 - 1mm.

It is possible to add an aluminum baffle to increase the refraction of the filament (under the bulb: 0.5 - 1mm of space).

Support pour ampoule C5W ( Feux de position )

Ce modèle a été réalisé avec TinkerCAD, afin de remplacer les support d'ampoules d'origines d'une Land Rover Serie 1 (1952) qui avaient complètement rouillé et n'était plus stable.

L'ampoule est maintenue par pression/tension du support (aucun mouvement possible, perfect fit). Il faudra rajouter 2 contacteur males de 0,8 - 1mm.

Il est possible de rajouter un déflecteur en aluminium pour augmenter la refraction du filament (sous l'ampoule: 0,5 - 1mm d'espace).

Die Gebäude der Hersteller sehen zwar soweit ganz gut aus, es gibt aber wirklich nur DIESE EINE Variante pro Gebäude und die Teile sind recht teuer.

Es gibt aber im "WWW" einige Seiten auf denen sog. Papiermodelle (Papercraft) vorgestellt und zum Download zur Verfügung gestellt werden.

Es erfordert sicherlich ein wenig Geschick die (selbst zu druckenden) Modelle zusammenzubauen, aber der Aufwand lohnt sich!

Zum Bau empfiehlt es sich auf Fotokarton zu drucken, soweit das mit dem Drucker möglich ist. Ansonsten auf Papier drucken und auf die 3D Druckteile kleben.

Eine dünne Schicht Kleber genügt zum Anbringen, weicht das Papier nicht auf und scheint auch nicht durch.

Eine sehr schöne Seite für den (kostenlosen) Download von Papiergebäuden und Dekoration ist: www.carrera4fun.de

Ebenfalls absolut empfehlenswert ist die Seite vom Peter: Pedemann Online

author: denwer4u

description.text:
This is my design for a quadruped. Most 3 Degrees of Freedom (DoF) legs also have 3 parts to the legs. I wanted to see if it was possible to get 2 DoF from one joint. Design Decisions:
  • I then decided to go with a cable drive and keep the servo's inside the body, rather than make them part of the leg as most others have.
  • Make it modular so that you can attach what ever size servo's you want, to it. I have not included the central square into the downloadable files as this would depend on the size of servos you choose to use as well as what and where you would like to mount any electronics and/or sensors or cameras you want to include.
  • The two part leg should print pre-assembled. There is 0.2mm gap so even a normal self build 3D printer should be able to print this. I sliced this with KISSlicer64 but be sure to enable "Avoid Crossing Perimeters" in your slicing program. I found that Slic3r does not slice this thing right and screws up the design. Let me know if you have better luck.
    • The first part of the leg is just over 120mm long and the second part is about half that, so it should just fit onto a 200mm x 200mm heatbed with a couple of mm to spare or you could rotate it 45 degrees if it's to close. I would love to hear feedback if anyone finds any bugs or if you have any bright ideas.

The idea with this was to get all the servos in the body and use cables to articulate the legs, You'll notice little "notches" just before the hinge on the long part of the leg. You should push a 1mm diameter bar through these holes to allow the cable to then tie onto that. The cable should then be thread through the in line notch on the upper leg. Fishing line should work great (The non stretch variety).  
Similar notches are near the ball joint. 4 of them with 1 servo driving the opposite sides of the legs. Again these cables should be fed through the guides on the hip. The extra two guides on the hip are for the cables going to the lower leg.  
Gineer R&D

author: CBiker

description.text:
Since it was Veganuary and the chances of me following that diet hovered around the nil mark, I spotted a set of wargame rules called 'Palaeo Diet - Eat or Be Eaten' (from Ganesha Games and available as a pdf download from the Wargame Vault - can be played solo) and so reckoned that that would give me a moral diet advantage.
As usual when I find a set of wargame rules and have zero of the necessary figures and am too tight to buy any, I resort to throwing out some cheap, quick and simple flat minis to cover the gap, and so I throw them your way.
The animals are largely 3 or 4 pieces representing a left and right side with legs and ears on, and a middle piece to carry the tail and to give the animal some width (in a flat sort of way) - see the deer piccy attached -you'll get the idea. Animals currently attached are:
-woolly mammoth
-deer
-wild goats
-wolves (have an alternative mid section for variety)
-sabre-tooth tiger
with more to follow
The hunters are one piece and comprise hunters holding spear,bow,fire!, and club as per the rules.
I also include a fire marker, some rulers for S,M and L distances, and I'm sure you can find some D6s

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

Fine

Notes:

Trees - I was adding some tree trunks to the foliage when I remembered that my slicer has a branch-style support option, so being lazy I suspended the foliage vertically above the plate on the slicer, set the branch support to 4 mm and let the software fill in the trunks. They came out OK really. The smaller foliage is for using as bushes. I did all of these on a 5% fill. Vary the scale to provide a variety of heights.
Rulers - One file has the rulers for short, medium and long distances in. If your plate isn't big enough, I've loaded a second file with the long distance ruler in two halves for gluing together. Plan B - use a ruler!
Deer - I've provided a full set of antlers for the deer. For young deer and females I just printed out a set of antlers and shortened them with clippers to get the desired length/effect.

The animals

As a source of reference I have used a few screen pics from one of my favourite PC games - Far Cry Primal, and hand-drawn a set of splines, then extruded them to create the flats. One day I'll get round to doing them properly!

title: Prusa MK2/MK2S ext. driver board box

description.text:
This box is designed to fit my external driver board for the original Prusa MK2/MK2s printers.

It's is an external stepper driver board for X and Y stepper motors of the original Prusa MK2/MK2S printers. It allows usage of TMC2100 (Silent Step Stick and similar) drivers, so your printer will become a lot quieter and much smoother due to the 256 step interpolation (same as on the MK3).

More information about the board here:

https://vmod.wordpress.com/prusa-mk2s-ext-driver-board/

You will need some supports to print the box.
I've included versions without the voltmeter and without the Noctua fan.
Noctua fan should be 40x40x10, 12V.

description.text: I took the amazing Mini Maker Faire Rhode Island logo created by Josie Morway ( http://www.josiemorway.com ) and made it a 3D printable object that is perfect for a keychain. Print your own or better yet, back our Kickstarter for $25 or more to help support the Faire and we will print one for you and mail it to you! http://www.kickstarter.com/projects/143072809/rhode-island-mini-maker-faire-2012?ref=live

Print the AnchorPlate.stl then slice open the 3 rings with a knife, razor, or sharp wire cutters. Join the 3 wrings together to make a chain then attach them to the anchor. Finally drop a little acetone (careful it's nasty stuff) onto the cracks and push them together to seal them back closed. You are ready to slide the other end of the chain onto your keyring and show your maker support.

description.text: This Hotend Mount & Fan Shroud allow you to use your original hotend carriage plate, bolts (although some may need slightly longer bolts) and 40mm cooling fan to mount E3 style hotends. It was also designed to reduce weight as much as possible while still using the stock carriage plate. This part prints in 4 pieces: The Mount (file 1), the Mount Strap (file 2), the Fan Shroud (file 3), and the Fan Shroud Top Piece (file 4). Print in ABS and glue the Top Piece to the Fan Shroud with Acetone. Then, glue the Fan Shroud assembly to the Mount as shown in the pictures and hold while drying with a fan mount screw. Then, just mount the fan and hotend.

This design allows you to use your original hotend carriage plate and 40mm fan. You may have to use slightly longer mounting screws.

print_settings.Notes:: Print with flexible filament! I used FilaFlex TPE.

description.text:
Some time ago I decided to design one of the smallest possible 3" FPV racers.
It fits 3" props, 13xx-14xx motors, a 20x20 FC and a runcam mikro swift (or similarly sized camera).

31*31mm hardware would fit the frame as well (45° rotated to the flying axis), my pod will not fit anymore then, as it uses the 31mm holes as mounting points.

The pod is designed to be printed using flexible filament, without supports (though it will sag a bit in the rear).

It flies amazingly well and is a lot of fun, as well as very hard to break. Building can be a little tricky and frustrating, as everything has to fit underneath the pod somehow... I managed, so you will manage as well, though. And the result is totally worth it.

My hardware (guaranteed to fit, similar hardware should of course fit as well):

  • HGLRC F428 (FC + 4in1 ESC stack)
  • Armattan Oomph 1407 (shafts are very fragile, stay clear of them)
  • HQprops 3x4x3v1s
  • Furious FPV Stealth (no Bluetooth, but it would fit somehow)
  • RotorX u.fl Whip antenna
  • Runcam Micro Swift 2
  • FRsky R-XSR (antennas taped to the inside of the pod)
  • 4S 850mAh Acehe
    Total weight (with a 3mm base plate) ~260g.

title: 2 Color Mastercam Logo
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
The design was created in an imperial coordinate system, so you might need to scale this design by 25.4X depending on your slicer's default settings.

I printed the inserts separately from the base and popped all the parts together once I had everything. This design is suitable for dual extrusion though!

The STL files are oriented logo face-down by default, but I recommend rotating the base 180 deg about X or Y before printing, to minimize supports.

Keep the insert upside down on the print bed, unless you are dual extruding. Since first layer of a 3D print tends to be thicker than subsequent layers, you're better off trying to fit the top of the insert into the base first. The other reason for doing it this way is that any over extrusion on that first layer will help seal up the seam between the two parts, if you print the parts with the orientations I'm suggesting.

Designed in Mastercam 2017

Made with Solid bodies, Wireframe base geometry, and impressions to create the inserts.

title: Toranado Power Tower Raspberry Pi Ramps 1.4 Full Graphics

description.text:
New improved version of the original popular thing: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:894503
(note original thing, includes many useful electronics components 3D STL models for reference, remix, design, etc...)

Improvements:

Pass thru header connector system!!!
larger more stable base
Toranado Extruder themed styling https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1246951
Full Graphics Controller
Raspberry Pi mounted inside unit (with power converter)
Mounting provisions for both Mechanical or Mosfet relay boards for heat bed
(BIQU Heat Bed Mosfet Relay STL model included here for reference)

Details, links for electronic components & firmware downloads are at http://bigcooter.com/?p=1584!

The pass thu header connector system utilizes popular JST connectors for hot end and auxiliary circuits. The stepper motors and sensors utilize Dupont pin headers (simply pull out pins at ends and where dividers exist in the printed parts). The high current heating bed 2 circuits are now designed for using Aptiv / Delphi 2.8mm automotive terminals (male terminals locked in place with self tapping screws, mates to commercially available Aptiv unsealed 2way APEX 2.8 female connector, the male connector once printed, undercut the locking tab with an exacto knife so mating commercial 2way connector properly locks up ... another option for this connection could be to use the popular XT-60 connector used on my R/C battery connectors (feel free to remix and contribute!). NOTE: I have include one Pin-Out example, file which can be altered, printed out and taped to back of unit for reference, highly recommended!!

APEX 2.8 terminals / connectors available at Mouser
https://www.mouser.com/Delphi-Connection-Systems/Connectors/Automotive-Connectors/APEX-28-Series/_/N-1ehb5?P=1yzmthrZ1z0zlez

The "Outlet Spacer" is optional, using it provides additional internal space ... to seperate high voltage leads from circuit boards.

Raspberry Pi "light pipes" in base, are made from any translucent 1.75mm printer filament. Trim one end with razor blade, insert into base hole, then flush cut with razor blade, simple!

Disclaimer for cry babies with lawyers: When fully assembled, the maker assumes full responsibility for their assembled unit ... remember, this is not a UL approved commercial item, nor has my design been optimized for your safety. Be responsible, build safe, ... if bad things happen, it's on you.

The base is shown as printed (upside-down) to minimize support. The rectangular block outside the base is there to eliminate a tall, thin, unstable tower of support material which would separate from the print bed.

Also included is a DXF file of the bottom cover, which can either be 3D printed or laser cut out of acrylic.

If you want to make this, but lack access to a laser cutter, I've created an eBay listing where you can purchase an acrylic bottom cover together with all the screws needed to build this, and optionally the necessary amount of lead shot. Check out https://www.ebay.com/itm/273071446451

You can also buy the lead shot in larger quantities for this or other projects you may have.
One pound: https://www.ebay.com/itm/273079193757
Two pounds: https://www.ebay.com/itm/273079193753

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

0.15mm Layer Height

Notes:

Printed in PLA, 0.40 nozzle. Use concentric supports (everywhere). This makes removal easier and cleaner.

The print needs very little cleanup. The only difficult operation is removing the support material from under the bridge that supports the circuit board. I've found that a little prying with a small screwdriver, angled tweezers and needle nosed pliers works it out pretty well. After the electronics are installed, the base is filled with lead shot and a laser cut acrylic bottom cover is installed. All screw holes are sized for 2-56 screws to self tap.

description.text:
A divider that is meant to slide under packages on a shelf and display a label. The large part slides under the box and the label goes on the smaller part which is on the surface of the image. The name plate is just over 90mm across and 40mm wide, so works with standard Brother QL-500 labels and others with a little space either side (0.5mm).

It is printed with the label plate facing down with no supports and whatever fill you want. Many can be printed at once. I print 6 at a time on my TronXY X5S.

It has collapsed edges so that it wont get stuck and a thinner rear part to provider better stability.

Used as part of my business (ecommerce) to seperate and label sections on a shelf, without physically sticking a permanent label to the shelf itself. This allows me to move the products and reorganise them on a whim.

This is a key tag I created for an elementary school. Feel free to print for yourself and enjoy.

The historic Sputnik satellite, first human-made satellite in orbit, rendered here as a 3D-printer-friendly version. The focus here was to capture some of the finer details, and get a scale that allows that detail to be shown without ending up with a huge model.

There are other Sputniks available on Thingiverse - give those a try too. This one was created from scratch purely from inspecting photos of the real thing. The antenna mounts are particularly true-to-form, and the size is small enough that it won't take over your whole desk.

A big challenge with many spacecraft models is doing something practical with the antenna bits. What works nicely for me has been using straightened paper-clips, which are ubiquitous, and avoids the need to scale the body of the model up to a crazy size to allow 3D printing of very thin plastic pieces.

For such a simple structure, getting the balance of size vs detail right is a bit of a challenge, but I hope you'll agree the trade-offs make for a nice model.

There are TWO VERSIONS of the top section with the antenna mounts. One has manually added support bits you can break off and toss. The other has none, and leaves that for you to support as you please.

  • A single peg holds the two body halves together.
  • The stand assembles nicely for me - but use a bit of hot glue to secure any bits you wish.

Still in progress - will try to tweak a little more as time allows.

Check Out Some of my Other Space Probes

  • Cassini probe to Saturn
  • OSIRIS-REx probe to the asteroid Bennu

Clean-up antenna mounts, sand and or glue as desired

What I call the antenna 'nodes' are tiny little things. They're just on the edge of what my 3D printer is able to pull off. They need some clean-up with an exacto knife to get good results. Perhaps yours will work out better.

Thin, roughly cylindrical items don't 3D print vertically very well, as they are prone to breaking along the layer interfaces. Thus these were modelled to lay flat when printing. There's a little rib used to flatten the not-flat object to the printing bed.

YOU NEED TO TRIM the barrel of the antenna node that fits into the antenna mount to remove the flat support. It takes 2 seconds with a knife and then they push in to the hole easily.

Straighten a paper clip (or use a piece of wire if you wish) and insert into the holes in the antenna node pieces. A bit of hot glue here might help it stick. Small holes print with varying levels of success on different printers. :-/

As mentioned above, there are two versions of the main body top section. One includes a manually added support of the antenna inserts.

The stand snaps together for me, but it's probably more secure to use a bit of hot glue to keep it all together. (The stand base will also take a small screw if you'd rather do that.)

description.text: I found that gantry alignment on Raise3D printers can be done better than the recommended method. The recommended method is to align the distance from slider blocks to the end face of the belt pulleys. In reality, what you want, is to align the center shafts to be parallel to the gantry shafts. You therefore need spacer clips, like the ones I have designed here. They clip on the rods and ensure that shafts are parallel, before tightening all the pulley screws and slider block screws. The clips here are designed to put the center rods exactly in the middle of the gantry on the N1 printer. For that reason there are clips of two different lengths, one type for X and one type for Y. You can actually put clips on from both sides, if so wanted. For N2 printers the clips can only be used from one side.

title: Tiny Whoov Lite- Low Profile Inductrix Hovercraft

description.text:
Here's my take on the Tiny Whoov! This version requires you to run your props upside down on all four motors, and requires a sacrificial Inductrix frame for the two hover motors, optionally for the thrust motors. Flight controller holes are meant for m2 screws! I've also included an experimental airflow diffuser to help distribute the downwards thrust a little better. Requires some support material just for the underside! 15% worked just fine for me.

2/9/18- Added a version that has a 6x15 battery loop on the front, a perfect spot in the front to mount your camera with double sided tape, too. I also included a standalone camera mount which holds the camera 15mm above the FC, I haven't personally run this one yet so I'd love some feedback!

title: S6Edge Holder for Ultimaker 3 to make Timelapse Videos

description.text:
I made a holder for my old S6Edge to make timelapse videos of my Ultimaker 3.
I used and adjusted some designes, so first I want to give credit to:

T70E:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2615653
I used his hindge for the Ultimaker 3 door. Thank you!

littlebignita:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1241911
I used his S6Edge holder. Thank you!

The holder is mounted to the Ultimaker using some orignal screws.
The parts of the holder are glued together.

The parts:

UM_Mount_Top.stl
UM_Mount_Bottom.stl
-> This are the mounts using the original screws of the Ultimaker.

Rod.stl
-> This is the rod that sticks through the two mounts. I would not glue it to the mounts else you are not able to move the S6Edge out of the way anymore.

Bracket.stl
-> This bracked provides a 20° angle and is glued to the rod so it will not fall through the mounts.

Bracket_Lock.stl
-> I printed two of this locks and glued it to the bottom mount to lock the bracket in place but you are still able to lift the bracket over the lock and move the S6Edge out of the way when needed.

S6Edge_Holder.stl
-> This is the holder for the S6Edge. I glued it to the bracket in the right position and angle to capture good videos.
Of course you can use an other holder if you want to use an other mobile phone.

Software:
I use Framelapse Pro to capture timelapse videos. I tried many apps but this is the least worst.
To calculate the capture interval I use:
https://www.photopills.com/calculators/timelapse

Have fun!

description.text:
This is a piece made for the modular sabers blade. This is a great totally 3d printed blade, but after I made it, i found it loosy on the hilt, so I created this joint.

Also, I added a "small screw blade" to fit into the hilt instead of the blade.

Blade: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2753617

By the way, to improve the brightness you can introduce transparent cellophane film paper inside the blade. This helps the light to achieve more distance on the blade.
Also, you can glue blade pieces together to get a tighter and stronger blade you can even swoosh

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/lKvMftEbJ3p

Made to look like the health pack from Overwatch. I've made 2 of these for my nephews for Christmas.

I have uploaded the model several different ways. The models are all named with color, what type, and if more than one is needed.

If you have a large build height >= 210mm there are models that start with "Large Printer" and if your build volume is <= 150mm tall I have split the model into 3 pieces labeled "Small Printer". I split the model so that the seam is behind another part and you won't see it.

There are solid models that will need to be printed in vase mode or hollow models so you can pick based on the performance of your printer. The red plus symbol is in the orientation that gave me the best results, just print it with supports. The top and bottom black pieces are in the correct orientation for printing as well and I was able to print without supports and only had minor stringing, again depends on the performance of your printer, up to you if you use supports or not. I printed the lamp shade with 0 infill and only 1 perimeter and the result was acceptable but I would like to mess with the settings a little bit more.

The assembly is pretty straightforward just a bit of glue, hot or otherwise. Test fit everything first some of the parts kind of press fit together. The red plus part is just glued on. When I get time I have an idea for tabs to snap all the pieces together.

(Amazon affiliate links start..... now) It is modeled to use the oh so popular Hemma Cord http://amzn.to/2E3VInh from Ikea and I would recommend the shortest 40w equivalent Led Bulb (like thesehttp://amzn.to/2FCZy45 Short Led Bulb and these http://amzn.to/2DSToAd Led Bulbs)

Let me know if you have any questions, if you make one please post it, and I give you permission to get some other Overwatch stuff http://amzn.to/2E1PRPB to go along with your new lamp. The Amazon affiliate links support me at no extra cost to you.
Thanks for looking!

title: Gnarly Mini-Rambo Case
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The Gnarly MiniRambo Case

There are three options for front covers, Sexy, Plain, or a step file that you can make your own. If you do and want to publish it your title should include "Gnarly MR" so it can be found via search or as a remix. MR=MiniRambo

You also have the choice of the solid lid, or pass through lid.

The board can either be mounted USB up (accessed by removing the lid), or USB down.

The Ultimachine Boards have not needed cooling fans in my use cases so this case has flow through cooling but a built in baffle to keep the dirt out. There is room in the lid to cut a hole for a 40mm fan for those of you that like to push your drivers to the extreme.

Makes a sexy addition to all machines including the V1 Engineering creations, MPCNC, LowRider CNC, MP3DP...

Other Gnarly for the Rambo, Archim 1, and Archim 2 here, https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2781322.

A simple wheel stop. Works with wheels with a diameter of 30 mm or less. I use them for an IKEA Helmer desk drawer unit.

Holder for 1.5ml cuvettes for use with a Perking Elmer Lambda 19 spectrophotometer, and is designed to fit over the existing dovetail mount.
Updated Feb 2016 to include both orientations.  There is an icon in the upper right corner of each showing the light path relative to the cuvette orientation.
The narrow version is the standard orientation, where the light beam takes the longer path through the rectangular cuvette.  The wide version rotates the cuvette 90° from standard, because some of my people wanted to do it that way.  Additional work was done to make the holders stronger, and to better key the holders for their orientation (my people discovered they could force cuvettes in the narrow orientation into the wide holder, which also breaks off the front of the old holder)
Can be printed in ABS or PLA.  We've had good luck using 0.2mm layer height and haven't seen any effects of print density on the result.

title: CR-10 chain link bowden and cable support

description.text:
Chain link style support assembly for bowden tube and cable bundle that allows free movement without z drooping. Slotted for skinny velcro or zip ties.

When I bundled the Bowden tube, cables, and the ezabl cord they were just heavy enough to droop lower than the gantry and get rubbed back and forth during prints. I designed this chain link style support in Blender that anchors at the extruder and velcro'd the bundle to it. It allows free xy movement but not z.

Printer:

CR-10 S4

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Try to minimize 'elephant foot', or too much bottom layer expansion. The tolerances are tight to minimize sag.

Assembly

First assemble at least a single pin segment to the extruder chainlink base and add a washer and a retaining clip. This allows slipping the assembly in place for mounting without removing the bowden tube fitting. Remove the two bed side top extruder cover screws and secure the chainlink base on top with two M3 12mm screws. Add links to suit and ensure free rotation - they should be snug but not stiff. I only needed 4 links.

Washers are used to snug the fit to remove play in the Z.

title: Chimera/cyclops Daughter plate with cooling duct

description.text:
I decided to design an alternative Daughter plate for the Modular Carriage for TEVO Black Widow designed by Elzariant (you can find it here https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1829292)

The original design was Elzariant (which I give to all the credits for the design of both the system and the daughter plate), I modified the original to fit a blower (I tried several duct and several axial fan, but I find lack of pressure every time) and I added a duct system for cooling the parts. Now it has a decent air flow and it seems to work well. I liked also to have the design the as compact as possible, so I came up with this thing.

There are two version:
one has a closed duct which blows all aroud the nozzle.
the second is opened on one side (it looks more like a "C") so it lets you mount easily your extruder.

I printed it in PETG 100% infill 0,4 mm nozzle 2 wall thickness
Support needed

description.text:
THIS DESIGN HAS BEEN MOVED TO YOUMAGINE:
https://www.youmagine.com/designs/hotshoe-for-dual-e27-umbrella-holder Reasons:
http://marcuswolschon.blogspot.de/2014/01/leaving-thingiverse.html This is a modification to
www.dealextreme.com/p/dual-e27-sockets-lamp-bulb-holder-flash-umbrella-bracket-103135?item=6?r=78675737
Alone it can be used for lighting video with 2 or in conjunction with
www.dealextreme.com/p/e27-to-dual-e27-light-lamp-bulb-adapter-converter-94131?item=2&r=78675737
with 4 light bulps as a very strong video light.
With a large umbrella it's a soft and and without a hard video light. When you want photo and video, this modification allows to place a flash on the same umbrella.
The hot show is tapared to allow for easy insertion of the flash. I provided a technical drawing with the dimentions and spacing used, in case someone wants to design a different moficiation for this umbrella holder. blog posting:
http://marcuswolschon.blogspot.de/2012/08/umbrella-flash-holder.html

Unscrew the top plate.
Keep the 2 screws.
Slide on this part and insert the screws into the 2 center recesses.
You can use 4 additional screws for the edges. The original part has holes for 4 additional screws but does not use them. It can be a snug fit if your layer height is too large. In that case try to insert a flash while the plastic is still warm. The print you see was aborted after that damn Thing-o-Matic failed after 25 of 60 minutes. (The usual extruder-jamming when the PLA gets too hot due to an obvious design fault of the hot end.)

description.text:
This is a model of the SU122 Assault gun, in 28mm.
I took the body of Bergman's one piece print and upscaled it to 28mm. I sliced off the tracks, as printing with such a large tank in one piece would require a lot of support and post-print trimming. I then took the excellent tracks for Tiger Ace's T-34 pack (the 1942 tracks) and created protrusion on the back of the track pieces and recesses on the hull to allow easier alignment when assembling.
Please note the recess/protrusion fit is purposely loose, and I use epoxy to assemble the tracks to the hull; it may be too loose to use CA glue, as that requires a tight fit to work. I didn't want to make it too tight, as the manner another print make perform could cause an issue.
Also, please be sure to assemble the tracks pointed the correct way. The three tightly spaced bogie wheels are towards the rear; the two more widely spaced ones go towards the front.
Lastly, please use supports and rafts when printing!

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

PLEASE Use Support and rafts when printing!

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/4ySisaRPoeV

This spool holder fits over the top of the Dremel 3D20 and allows the use of most of the larger 1 kg filament spools. This was modified from a version found on GrabCAD (https://grabcad.com/library/dremel-3d20-filament-spool-holder-1) and improvements could still be made. I would probably port the main arm a little more to save filament, but it is very strong and the larger axle piece holds the heavier spools with no issue.

The original design didn't have much for a keeper at the end of the axle, so I added that. The original also mounted on the left side of the back of the printer and included a separate filament guide that mounted on the right side. I found that if you mount the filament holder on the right side, there is no need for any additional guide.

Post-Printing Adjustment?

Depending on the shrink rate of the filament used to print this, some slight filing/sanding might be necessary on the mount portion to get it to securely mount to the back of the printer. Don't take off too much material, as you want a very snug fit. The horizontal bottom of the mount should rest parallel to the top of the printer.

This is a pretty utilitarian accessory and this v. 1.0 design could definitely be cleaned up a bit after printing (and maybe even before).

description.text:
This is my first attempt at designing a lighted frame box for displaying 3D-printed lithophanes. It has three 50x80mm openings and one 164x80mm opening. Lithophanes to fit should be printed at 53x83mm and 167x83mm, all 1.5mm thick. The lithophanes mount in an insert which fits inside the front of the case; a front panel snaps on to hold the lithophanes in place. It's easy to swap out lithophanes by flexing the front panel slightly and removing it.

EDIT 2/4/18 - I've been experimenting with different thicknesses of lithophane ... 1.5mm is a little thin, and results in more visible artifacts because you don't have all that many 'shades of grey'. I've been getting better results with slightly thicker lithophanes - 2 or 2.5mm. You just need to make sure the outer 1.5mm of each lithophane is not too thick, so that they fit beneath the front frame. I've been getting good results by printing at 2.5mm, with a 60% gray border (1.5mm wide) in the original photo so that the outer edge of the final lithophane is less than 2mm thick.

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Select V2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

You may need to rotate the mounting insert and front panel before printing; the front panel should be printed with supports. The front panel STL file includes decorative 1mm 'trenches'; it should be possible to switch filaments if you like so the bottoms of the trenches are a different color from the rest of the panel (I haven't had a chance to do this yet but will post a photo once I do - the photos of the front panel currently posted are from a previous version, which did not have the trenches). The rear panel is attached with M3 screws.

EDIT 2/3/18 - I added a rear support that allows you to set the frame at a range of angles - you need an M3 bolt (10mm or 12mm) and nut to attach the lower adjustable strut. I didn't include holes in the back panel to attach the support, so you would need to drill holes to attach the support if you want to use it.

Requires an LED self-adhesive strip (e.g. https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01FHNJUGO/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1), mounted around the inside of the case. There is a 14mm x 28mm cutout in the rear panel for a rocker switch (https://www.amazon.com/Gardner-Bender-GSW-41-Appliance-Rocker/dp/B000BVZBPW/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1517506510&sr=8-1&keywords=Gardner+Bender+gsw-41). I glued a piece of aluminum foil to the inside of the back panel to direct the light forward to illuminate the lithophanes.
