This a collection primarily based off of honey and bee's.There's is a bee hive pencil holder with pencil slots that replicate honeycombs, A wire slot organizer that has a hive inspired front, and a tape dispenser that looks like a bee. The pencil holder is useful for regular wooden pencils, not mechanical. Also has a stand at the bottom that reads "Honey". The wire has two different sized types of wire slots and stands well by itself. Lastly, the bee tape dispenser is very adorable and with 2 smaller additional pieces, is very useful.Overall, this project took us between 10-15 hrs to make.

In our assignment, we did have restrictions so we had to stay in the invisible box of 10cm10cm10cm for filament saving purposes. However, I did change them when I printed out the second time. I had to create the hive shape with enough space on the top for the slots. Then for the slots, I had to create just one hole and fill pattern the rest. So we could meet requirements, we had lofted the bottom base to look like a circus stand.For finishing touches, I made the words "honey" with both the letter and spline tool. it was suppose to replicate the same font from an album cover of one of my favorite singers, Kehlani Parish.

Similarly, for the wire we designed the front face hive hexagons. Then we extruded it out a little bit. Originally, the front face was just extruded 1 cm. Knowing that wouldn't hold the wire well, we extended the design longer so it could be able to stay on the desk sturdier.

With the tape dispenser, my partner did majority of the design on this bee since we only need to pieces for the whole collection and it ended up being an extra part to tie the other two together. When we printed it out to full scale, it looked cool overall, but the tape slot had a few issues staying on and needed to be secure. Furthermore, I created two additional pieces that would extend the spool for the tape and make the tap stick on.

Note: if you are trying to print the bee dispenser, print the stopper and extender also and glue the extender to the spool on the bee.

For engineering class, we had an office supplies assignment to make two or more cool creations that could be also used for organization or typical desktop items. My partner and I came up with the idea of honey comb and bee's to be the main vocal point. We wanted most people to see our supplies as very useful with a cute touch.
Creating this piece, we used Soildworks to sketch and design. After printed, we did use sand paper and hot glue to fix minor mistakes

description.text:
Here he is in all of his glory - good ol' Flat Stanley! I started with a JPG of Stanley and converted it to a .stl at www.selva3d.com. I imported the .stl into TinkerCAD and realized that if I printed him as is his eyes, nose, and mouth would just fall out. No one wants a faceless Stanley :(

First thing I did was duplicate the .stl file in TinkerCAD. We will call this "Top Stanley".

I shrunk Original Stanley's z-height down to 1mm and surrounded him with shapes (also 1mm in height) so that all his outside geometry was touching another piece of geometry. I built him out so that he was inside of a 115mmx85.25mm rectangle comprised of overlapping shapes. I grouped all the shapes.

I turned this grouping of shapes into a hole and aligned it over another rectangle 85.25x115x1mm. I grouped them. The result is "Bottom Stanley".

I adjusted T.S.'s height, aligned, and finally grouped the two Stanleys.

Boom.

CCSS

Flat Stanley goes 3D. Combine reading and geography with technology to take Flat Stanley off the page and into your house or classroom. Introduce students to 3D printing while furthering the Flat Stanley narrative or use your 3D printed Flat Stanley to help teach the concept of dimensions and multiple planes. Teachers and students can use additive and subtractive geometry within TinkerCAD to add and take away features like his hair and tie.

What if...? What if Stanley wasn't flat? Is there a way we can take Digital Stanley from the computer and turn him into a real object that we create, hold, and photograph in different locations? You betcha. Download the attached .stl file, slice for your 3D printer and watch your students' awe as an old friend is reborn. This is a great way to introduce young students to early 3D printing vocabulary like filament, layer height, and the basic parts of the printer. If used with older elementary students (3rd grade and up), this is a great springboard into the design process. Stanley won't be finished before students start asking, "What can we print next?" Students can then "tinker this" design to customize Stanley to look like themselves or their teachers.

• Design
  • Reading
  • Technology

  • geometry
1-2 Days

Know your printer... This works best if students can watch the 3D printer work. You will want to familiarize yourself with how the printer works, what materials you are printing with, how to slice .stl files and other basics that will help this go smoothly. Printing in a classroom? Don't use ABS plastic. It gives off a noxious and potentially harmful stink. I suggest using PLA instead.
